# Army of the Potomac

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the Union army. For the Confederate army of the same
name, see [Confederate Army of the
Potomac](/wiki/Confederate_Army_of_the_Potomac "Confederate Army of the
Potomac").

The **Army of the Potomac** was the principal [Union Army](/wiki/Union_Army
"Union Army") in the [Eastern
Theater](/wiki/Eastern_Theater_of_the_American_Civil_War "Eastern Theater of
the American Civil War") of the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War
"American Civil War"). It was created in July 1861 shortly after the [First
Battle of Bull Run](/wiki/First_Battle_of_Bull_Run "First Battle of Bull Run")
and was disbanded in May 1865 following the
[surrender](/wiki/Battle_of_Appomattox_Court_House "Battle of Appomattox Court
House") of the Confederate [Army of Northern
Virginia](/wiki/Army_of_Northern_Virginia "Army of Northern Virginia") in
April.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Army_of_the_Potomac&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

The Army of the [Potomac](/wiki/Potomac_River#History "Potomac River") was
created in 1861 but was then only the size of a corps (relative to the size of
Union armies later in the war). Its nucleus was called the **Army of
Northeastern Virginia** , under [Brig.
Gen.](/wiki/Brigadier_general_\(United_States\) "Brigadier general \(United
States\)") [Irvin McDowell](/wiki/Irvin_McDowell "Irvin McDowell"), and it was
the army that fought (and lost) the war's first major battle, the [First
Battle of Bull Run](/wiki/First_Battle_of_Bull_Run "First Battle of Bull
Run"). The arrival in [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington,
D.C."), of [Maj. Gen.](/wiki/Major_general_\(United_States\) "Major general
\(United States\)") [George B. McClellan](/wiki/George_B._McClellan "George B.
McClellan") dramatically changed the makeup of that army. McClellan's original
assignment was to command the [Division of the
Potomac](/w/index.php?title=Division_of_the_Potomac&action=edit&redlink=1
"Division of the Potomac \(page does not exist\)"), which included the
[Department of Northeast
Virginia](/w/index.php?title=Department_of_Northeast_Virginia&action=edit&redlink=1
"Department of Northeast Virginia \(page does not exist\)") under McDowell and
the [Department of Washington](/wiki/Department_of_Washington "Department of
Washington") under Brig. Gen. [Joseph K. Mansfield](/wiki/Joseph_K._Mansfield
"Joseph K. Mansfield"). On July 26, 1861, the [Department of the
Shenandoah](/wiki/Department_of_the_Shenandoah "Department of the
Shenandoah"), commanded by Maj. Gen. [Nathaniel P.
Banks](/wiki/Nathaniel_P._Banks "Nathaniel P. Banks"), was merged with
McClellan's departments and on that day, McClellan formed the Army of the
Potomac, which was composed of all military forces in the former Departments
of Northeastern Virginia, Washington,
[Pennsylvania](/wiki/Department_of_Pennsylvania "Department of Pennsylvania"),
and the Shenandoah. The men under Banks's command became an infantry division
in the Army of the Potomac.[1] The army started with four corps, but these
were divided during the [Peninsula Campaign](/wiki/Peninsula_Campaign
"Peninsula Campaign") to produce two more. After the [Second Battle of Bull
Run](/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Bull_Run "Second Battle of Bull Run"), the Army of
the Potomac absorbed the units that had served under Maj. Gen. [John
Pope](/wiki/John_Pope_\(military_officer\) "John Pope \(military officer\)").

It is a popular, but mistaken, belief that John Pope commanded the Army of the
Potomac in the summer of 1862 after McClellan's unsuccessful Peninsula
Campaign. On the contrary, Pope's army consisted of different units, and was
named the [Army of Virginia](/wiki/Army_of_Virginia "Army of Virginia").
During the time that the Army of Virginia existed, the Army of the Potomac was
headquartered on the [Virginia Peninsula](/wiki/Virginia_Peninsula "Virginia
Peninsula"), and then outside Washington, D.C., with McClellan still in
command, although three corps of the Army of the Potomac were sent to northern
Virginia and were under Pope's operational control during the [Northern
Virginia Campaign](/wiki/Northern_Virginia_Campaign "Northern Virginia
Campaign").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/The_Army_of_the_Potomac_
--_Our_Outlying_Picket_in_the_Woods.jpg/220px-The_Army_of_the_Potomac_--
_Our_Outlying_Picket_in_the_Woods.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Army_of_the_Potomac_--
_Our_Outlying_Picket_in_the_Woods.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Army_of_the_Potomac_--_Our_Outlying_Picket_in_the_Woods.jpg
"Enlarge")

_The Army of the Potomac – Our Outlying Picket in the Woods_ , 1862

The Army of the Potomac underwent many structural changes during its
existence. The army was divided by [Ambrose Burnside](/wiki/Ambrose_Burnside
"Ambrose Burnside") into three grand divisions of two corps each with a
Reserve composed of two more. Hooker abolished the grand divisions. Thereafter
the individual corps, seven of which remained in Virginia, reported directly
to army headquarters. Hooker also created a Cavalry Corps by combining units
that previously had served as smaller formations. In late 1863, two corps were
sent West, and— in 1864— the remaining five corps were recombined into three.
Burnside's [IX Corps](/wiki/IX_Corps_\(ACW\) "IX Corps \(ACW\)"), which
accompanied the army at the start of [Ulysses S. Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant
"Ulysses S. Grant")'s [Overland Campaign](/wiki/Overland_Campaign "Overland
Campaign"), rejoined the army later. For more detail, see the section
**Corps** below.

The Army of the Potomac fought in most of the Eastern Theater campaigns,
primarily in (Eastern) Virginia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania. After the end of
the war, it was disbanded on June 28, 1865, shortly following its
participation in the [Grand Review of the
Armies](/wiki/Grand_Review_of_the_Armies "Grand Review of the Armies").

The **Army of the Potomac** was also the name given to General [P. G. T.
Beauregard](/wiki/P._G._T._Beauregard "P. G. T. Beauregard")'s
[Confederate](/wiki/Confederate_States_Army "Confederate States Army") army
during the early stages of the war (namely, First Bull Run; thus, the losing
Union Army ended up adopting the name of the winning Confederate army).
However, the name was eventually changed to the [Army of Northern
Virginia](/wiki/Army_of_Northern_Virginia "Army of Northern Virginia"), which
became famous under General [Robert E. Lee](/wiki/Robert_E._Lee "Robert E.
Lee").

In 1869 the [Society of the Army of the
Potomac](/wiki/Society_of_the_Army_of_the_Potomac "Society of the Army of the
Potomac") was formed as a veterans association. It had its last reunion in
1929.

## Famous
units[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Army_of_the_Potomac&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Famous units")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Civil_War_steeplechase2.jpg/220px-
Civil_War_steeplechase2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Civil_War_steeplechase2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Civil_War_steeplechase2.jpg "Enlarge")

[Saint Patrick's Day](/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Day "Saint Patrick's Day")
celebration in the Army of the Potomac, depicting a
[steeplechase](/wiki/Steeplechase_\(horse_racing\) "Steeplechase \(horse
racing\)") race among the [Irish Brigade](/wiki/Irish_Brigade_\(U.S.\) "Irish
Brigade \(U.S.\)"), March 17, 1863, by [Edwin Forbes](/wiki/Edwin_Forbes
"Edwin Forbes")

Because of its proximity to the large cities of the North, such as
[Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."),
[Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia,_Pennsylvania "Philadelphia, Pennsylvania"),
and [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), the Army of the
Potomac received more contemporary media coverage than the other Union field
armies. Such coverage produced fame for a number of this army's units.
Individual brigades, such as the [Irish Brigade](/wiki/Irish_Brigade_\(U.S.\)
"Irish Brigade \(U.S.\)"), the [Philadelphia
Brigade](/wiki/Philadelphia_Brigade "Philadelphia Brigade"), the [First New
Jersey Brigade](/wiki/First_New_Jersey_Brigade "First New Jersey Brigade"),
the [Vermont Brigade](/wiki/Vermont_Brigade "Vermont Brigade"), and the [Iron
Brigade](/wiki/Iron_Brigade "Iron Brigade"), all became well known to the
general public, both during the Civil War and afterward.

### Corps[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Army_of_the_Potomac&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Corps")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Scouts_and_guides_Army_of_the_Potomac.jpg/220px-
Scouts_and_guides_Army_of_the_Potomac.jpg)](/wiki/File:Scouts_and_guides_Army_of_the_Potomac.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Scouts_and_guides_Army_of_the_Potomac.jpg "Enlarge")

Scouts and guides, Army of the Potomac, [Mathew Brady](/wiki/Mathew_Brady
"Mathew Brady")

The army originally consisted of fourteen divisions commanded by [Edwin
Sumner](/wiki/Edwin_Sumner "Edwin Sumner"), [William B.
Franklin](/wiki/William_B._Franklin "William B. Franklin"), [Louis
Blenker](/wiki/Louis_Blenker "Louis Blenker"), [Nathaniel
Banks](/wiki/Nathaniel_Banks "Nathaniel Banks"), [Frederick W.
Lander](/wiki/Frederick_W._Lander "Frederick W. Lander"), [Silas
Casey](/wiki/Silas_Casey "Silas Casey"), [Irvin McDowell](/wiki/Irvin_McDowell
"Irvin McDowell"), [Fitz-John Porter](/wiki/Fitz-John_Porter "Fitz-John
Porter"), [Samuel Heintzelman](/wiki/Samuel_Heintzelman "Samuel Heintzelman"),
[Erasmus Keyes](/wiki/Erasmus_Keyes "Erasmus Keyes"), [William F.
Smith](/wiki/William_Farrar_Smith "William Farrar Smith"), [Charles P.
Stone](/wiki/Charles_Pomeroy_Stone "Charles Pomeroy Stone") (replaced by John
Sedgwick in February 1862), and [George McCall](/wiki/George_McCall "George
McCall"). Because this arrangement would be too hard to control in battle,
President Lincoln issued an order on March 13, 1862, dividing the army into
six corps headed by Sumner, Banks (despite being in the Shenandoah Valley and
not part of the main army), McDowell, Heintzelman, and Keyes, the highest-
ranking officers. McClellan was not happy with this, as he had intended to
wait until the army had been tested in battle before judging which generals
were suitable for corps command.

After the [Battle of Williamsburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Williamsburg "Battle of
Williamsburg") on May 5, McClellan requested and obtained permission to create
two additions corps; these became the V Corps, headed by Brig. Gen Fitz-John
Porter, and the VI Corps, headed by Brig. Gen William B. Franklin, both
personal favorites of his. After the Battle of Kernstown in the Valley on
March 23, the administration became paranoid about ["Stonewall"
Jackson](/wiki/Stonewall_Jackson "Stonewall Jackson")'s activities there and
the potential danger they posed to Washington D.C., and to McClellan's
displeasure, detached Blenker's division from the II Corps and sent it to West
Virginia to serve under [John C. Fremont](/wiki/John_C._Fremont "John C.
Fremont")'s command. McDowell's corps was detached as well and stationed in
the Rappahannock area.

In June 1862, George McCall's division from McDowell's corps (the
[Pennsylvania Reserves](/wiki/Pennsylvania_Reserves "Pennsylvania Reserves")
Division) was sent down to the Peninsula and temporarily attached to the V
Corps. In the Seven Days Battles, the V Corps was heavily engaged. The
Pennsylvania Reserves, in particular, suffered heavy losses including its
division commander, who was captured by the Confederates, and two of its three
brigadiers ([John F. Reynolds](/wiki/John_F._Reynolds "John F. Reynolds"),
also captured, and [George Meade](/wiki/George_Meade "George Meade"), who was
wounded). The III Corps fought at Glendale, however, the rest of the army was
not heavily engaged in the week-long fight aside from Slocum's division of the
VI Corps, which was sent to reinforce the V Corps at Gaines Mill.

The Army of the Potomac remained on the Virginia Peninsula until August, when
it was recalled back to Washington D.C. Keyes and one of the two IV Corps
divisions were left behind permanently as part of the newly-created Department
of the James, while the other division, commanded by Brig. Gen Darius Couch
was attached to the VI Corps.

During the Second Battle of Bull Run, the III and V Corps were temporarily
attached to Pope's army; the former suffered major losses and was sent back to
Washington to rest and refit afterward, so it did not participate in the
Maryland Campaign. The V Corps attracted controversy during the battle when
Fitz-John Porter failed to execute Pope's orders properly and attack Stonewall
Jackson's flank despite his protests that James Longstreet's troops were
blocking the way. Pope blamed the loss at Second Bull Run on Porter, who was
court-martialed and spent much of his life attempting to get himself
exonerated. Sigel's command, now redesignated the XI Corps, also spent the
Maryland Campaign in Washington resting and refitting.

In the Maryland Campaign, the Army of the Potomac had six corps. These were
the I Corps, commanded by Joe Hooker after Irvin McDowell was removed from
command, the II Corps, commanded by Edwin Sumner, the V Corps, headed by Fitz-
John Porter, the VI Corps, headed by William Franklin, the IX Corps, headed by
Ambrose Burnside and formerly the Department of North Carolina, and the XII
Corps, headed by Nathaniel Banks until September 12, and given to Joseph K.
Mansfield just two days prior to Antietam, where he was killed in action.

At Antietam, the I and XII Corps were the first Union outfits to fight and
both corps suffered enormous casualties (plus the loss of their commanders) so
that they were down to near-division strength and their brigades at regimental
strength after the battle was over. The II and IX Corps were also heavily
engaged but the V and VI Corps largely stayed out of the battle.

When Burnside took over command of the army from McClellan in the fall, he
formed the army into four Grand Divisions. The Right Grand Division was
commanded by Edwin Sumner and comprised the II and V Corps, the Center Grand
Division, commanded by Joe Hooker, comprised the IX and III Corps, and the
Left Grand Division, commanded by William Franklin, comprised the VI and I
Corps. In addition, the Reserve Grand Division, commanded by Franz Sigel,
comprised the XI and XII Corps.

At Fredericksburg, the I Corps was commanded by John F. Reynolds, the II Corps
by Darius Couch, the III Corps by George Stoneman, the V Corps by Daniel
Butterfield, the VI Corps by William F. Smith, and the IX Corps by Orlando
Willcox. The XI Corps was commanded by Franz Sigel and the XII Corps by Henry
Slocum, however, neither corps was present at Fredericksburg, the former not
arriving until after the battle was over, and the latter was stationed at
Harper's Ferry.

Following Fredericksburg, Burnside was removed from command of the army and
replaced by Joe Hooker. Hooker immediately abolished the Grand Divisions and
also for the first time organized the cavalry into a proper corps led by
George Stoneman instead of having them ineffectually scattered among infantry
divisions. Burnside and his old IX Corps departed out to a command in the
Western Theater. The I, II, and XII Corps retained the same commanders they
had had during the Fredericksburg campaign, but the other corps got new
commanders once again. Daniel Butterfield was chosen by Hooker as his new
chief of staff and command of the V Corps went to George Meade. Daniel Sickles
received command of the III Corps and Oliver Howard the XI Corps after Franz
Sigel had resigned, refusing to serve under Hooker, his junior in rank.
William Franklin also left the army for the same reason. Edwin Sumner, who was
in his 60s and exhausted from campaigning, departed as well and died a few
months later. William F. Smith resigned from command of the VI Corps, which
was taken over by John Sedgwick. The I and V Corps were not significantly
engaged during the Chancellorsville campaign.

During the Gettysburg Campaign, the army's existing organization was largely
retained, but a number of brigades composed of short-term nine-month regiments
departed as their enlistment terms expired. Darius Couch resigned from command
of the II Corps after Chancellorsville, the corps going to Winfield Hancock.
The Pennsylvania Reserves Division, having spent several months in Washington
D.C. resting and refitting from the 1862 campaigns, returned to the army, but
was added to the V Corps rather than rejoining the I Corps. George Stoneman
had been removed from command of the cavalry corps by Hooker after a poor
performance during the Chancellorsville campaign and replaced by Alfred
Pleasanton.

George Meade was suddenly appointed the commander of the army on June 28, a
mere three days before the battle of Gettysburg. At the battle, the I, II, and
III Corps suffered such severe losses that they were almost nonfunctional as
fighting units at the end. One corps commander (Reynolds) was killed, another
(Sickles) lost a leg and was permanently out of the war, and a third (Hancock)
was badly wounded and never completely recovered from his injuries. The VI
Corps had not been significantly engaged and was mostly used to plug up holes
in the line during the battle.

For the remainder of the war, corps were added and subtracted from the army.
IV Corps was broken up after the Peninsula Campaign, with its headquarters and
2nd Division left behind in Yorktown, while its 1st Division moved north,
attached to the VI Corps, in the Maryland Campaign. Those parts of the IV
Corps that remained on the Peninsula were reassigned to the Department of
Virginia and disbanded on October 1, 1863.[2] Those added to the Army of the
Potomac were [IX Corps](/wiki/IX_Corps_\(Union_Army\) "IX Corps \(Union
Army\)"), [XI Corps](/wiki/XI_Corps_\(Union_Army\) "XI Corps \(Union Army\)")
([Sigel's](/wiki/Franz_Sigel "Franz Sigel") I Corps in the former [Army of
Virginia](/wiki/Army_of_Virginia "Army of Virginia")), [XII
Corps](/wiki/XII_Corps_\(Union_Army\) "XII Corps \(Union Army\)")
([Banks's](/wiki/Nathaniel_P._Banks "Nathaniel P. Banks") II Corps from the
[Army of Virginia](/wiki/Army_of_Virginia "Army of Virginia") ), added in
1862; and the [Cavalry
Corps](/wiki/Cavalry_Corps_\(Union_Army\)#Cavalry_Corps,_Army_of_the_Potomac
"Cavalry Corps \(Union Army\)"), created in 1863. Eight of these corps (seven
infantry, one cavalry) served in the army during 1863, but due to attrition
and transfers, the army was reorganized in March 1864 with only four corps:
II, V, VI, and Cavalry. Of the original eight, I and III Corps were disbanded
due to heavy casualties and their units combined into other corps. The XI and
XII Corps were ordered to the West in late 1863 to support the [Chattanooga
Campaign](/wiki/Chattanooga_Campaign "Chattanooga Campaign"), and while there
were combined into the XX Corps, never returning to the East.

The IX Corps returned to the army in 1864, after being assigned to the
[West](/wiki/Western_Theater_of_the_American_Civil_War "Western Theater of the
American Civil War") in 1863 and then served alongside, but not as part of,
the Army of the Potomac from March to May 24, 1864. On that latter date, IX
Corps was formally added to the Army of the Potomac.[3] Two divisions of the
Cavalry Corps have transferred in August 1864 to Maj. Gen. [Philip
Sheridan](/wiki/Philip_Sheridan "Philip Sheridan")'s [Army of the
Shenandoah](/wiki/Union_Army_of_the_Shenandoah "Union Army of the
Shenandoah"), and the 2nd Division alone remained under Meade's command. On
March 26, 1865, that division was also assigned to Sheridan for the closing
campaigns of the war.[4]

##
Commanders[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Army_of_the_Potomac&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Commanders")]

  * Brigadier General [Irvin McDowell](/wiki/Irvin_McDowell "Irvin McDowell"): Commander of the Army and Department of Northeastern Virginia (May 27 – July 25, 1861)
  * Major General [George B. McClellan](/wiki/George_B._McClellan "George B. McClellan"): Commander of the Military Division of the Potomac, and later, the Army and Department of the Potomac (July 26, 1861 – November 9, 1862)
  * Major General [Ambrose E. Burnside](/wiki/Ambrose_E._Burnside "Ambrose E. Burnside"): Commander of the Army of the Potomac (November 9, 1862 – January 26, 1863)
  * Major General [Joseph Hooker](/wiki/Joseph_Hooker "Joseph Hooker"): Commander of the Army and Department of the Potomac (January 26 – June 28, 1863)
  * Major General [George G. Meade](/wiki/George_G._Meade "George G. Meade"): Commander of the Army of the Potomac† (June 28, 1863 – June 28, 1865)

†Major General [John G. Parke](/wiki/John_G._Parke "John G. Parke") took brief
temporary command during Meade's absences on four occasions during this
period)

[Lt. Gen.](/wiki/Lieutenant_General_\(United_States\) "Lieutenant General
\(United States\)") [Ulysses S. Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S.
Grant"), general-in-chief of all Union armies, located his headquarters with
the Army of the Potomac and provided operational direction to Meade from May
1864 to April 1865, but Meade retained command of the Army of the Potomac.

## Major battles and
campaigns[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Army_of_the_Potomac&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Major battles and campaigns")]

  * [First Bull Run Campaign](/wiki/First_Battle_of_Bull_Run "First Battle of Bull Run") or First Manassas: McDowell (as "Army of Northeastern Virginia")
  * [Peninsula Campaign](/wiki/Peninsula_Campaign "Peninsula Campaign"), including the [Seven Days Battles](/wiki/Seven_Days_Battles "Seven Days Battles"): McClellan
  * [Northern Virginia Campaign](/wiki/Northern_Virginia_Campaign "Northern Virginia Campaign"), including the [Second Battle of Bull Run](/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Bull_Run "Second Battle of Bull Run") (I, XI, XII Corps participated under the control of the [Army of Virginia](/wiki/Army_of_Virginia "Army of Virginia"))
  * [Maryland Campaign](/wiki/Maryland_Campaign "Maryland Campaign"), including the [Battle of Antietam](/wiki/Battle_of_Antietam "Battle of Antietam") or Sharpsburg: McClellan
  * [Fredericksburg Campaign](/wiki/Battle_of_Fredericksburg "Battle of Fredericksburg"): Burnside
  * [Chancellorsville Campaign](/wiki/Battle_of_Chancellorsville "Battle of Chancellorsville"): Hooker
  * [Gettysburg Campaign](/wiki/Gettysburg_Campaign "Gettysburg Campaign"): Hooker/Meade (Meade appointed June 28, 1863)
  * [Bristoe Campaign](/wiki/Bristoe_Campaign "Bristoe Campaign"): Meade
  * [Mine Run Campaign](/wiki/Mine_Run_Campaign "Mine Run Campaign"): Meade
  * [Overland Campaign](/wiki/Overland_Campaign "Overland Campaign"): Meade
  * [Richmond-Petersburg Campaign](/wiki/Siege_of_Petersburg "Siege of Petersburg"), including the [Battle of the Crater](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Crater "Battle of the Crater"): Grant/Meade
  * [Appomattox Campaign](/wiki/Appomattox_Campaign "Appomattox Campaign"), including Lee's surrender at [Appomattox Court House](/wiki/Appomattox_Court_House_National_Historical_Park "Appomattox Court House National Historical Park"): Grant/Meade

## Casualties
breakdown[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Army_of_the_Potomac&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Casualties breakdown")]

battles](/wiki/List_of_costliest_American_Civil_War_land_battles "List of
costliest American Civil War land battles")

Below is the grand recapitulation of the losses susteined by the Army of the
Potomac and the [Army of the James](/wiki/Army_of_the_James "Army of the
James"), from May 5, 1864 to April 9, 1865, compiled in the Adjutant-General's
Office, Washington:
